channel.title: Carrier Grade NAT
channel.description:
I have one question is it possible to run a server off of a ISP that is using carrier Grade NAT or should i try and ask my ISP for a public IPV6 address
Edit: I say IPV6 because the world ran out of IPV4 addresses in 2008 or around there
I wasn't exactly sure where to put this it wasn't necessarily a server help question

item.title: Carrier Grade NAT
item.dc:creator: @ry60003333 ry60003333
item.description:
@ry60003333 wrote:

If you can get a computer with a public address to forward the traffic through then you can host a server from a Verzion LTE connection; I did it myself!

[center]It worked like this:


[/center]

Read full topic

item.title: Carrier Grade NAT
item.dc:creator: @military military
item.description:
@military wrote:

i will see if they will charge a fee for a public IP address would be my only option and you would be right people using older systems wont be able to see it thanks guys

Read full topic

item.title: Carrier Grade NAT
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

CGNAT is just NAT, it’s not like they did anything special to make it ‘carrier grade’ it just sounds nice. It’s going to prevent people connecting in to you, yes. Your ISP will probably still have v4 addresses to give you though - they may charge a fee for it. v6 is going to be fairly useless for running a server as not everyone has v6 visibility.

Read full topic

item.title: Carrier Grade NAT
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

The world hasn’t run out of IPv4’s. Otherwise everyone would have been forced to IPv6 by now. There are some computers that are still active today without IPv6 even on (in, i guess?) them.

If you’re talking carrier grade like a mobile hotspot that you’d get from verizon, then hell no.
If you’re talking carrier grade like a cell tower signal, I guess it’d depend on your ul/dl.
Otherwise, get a public IPv4

Read full topic
